instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Air Stuck In S5 State - Not Booting
threads.message:
Hello,

I have a MacBook Air that does not want to boot. Here are some of the voltages I have been looking at:

20 volts at the charger and cycling between 0.00 - 0.04 amps.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.6
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.3 volts
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> = 3.3 volts
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> = 0 volts
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> = 0 volts
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 1.8 volts
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 1.1 volts
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 0.8 volts
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 1.2 volts
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0.44 volts *****
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 0 volts

What should I check next?

I just realized G3S voltages missing typing this out..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Air Stuck In S5 State - Not Booting
threads.message: Here is a thermal view of the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Air Stuck In S5 State - Not Booting
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 0 volts"
Diode mode to ground?

All AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages must be present at the beginning.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Air Stuck In S5 State - Not Booting
threads.message:
Ohh, I see.

Diode mode for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 0.579

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> is actually 3 volts sorry about that.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0.40 volts and diode mode is 0.290

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Air Stuck In S5 State - Not Booting
threads.message: If [B][U]ALL[/U][/B] SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages are present, DFU mode is the next step...
